block.p: LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Early returns in Israel's election show a close race with the Likud party winning 40 seats and the Labor Party 38, but analysts said the pattern favored Yitzhak Shamir, the Likud leader. Page A1

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Early returns in Israel's election show a close race with the Likud party winning 40 seats and the Labor Party 38, but analysts said the pattern favored Yitzhak Shamir, the Likud leader. Page A1

INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Early returns in Israel's election show a close race with the Likud party winning 40 seats and the Labor Party 38, but analysts said the pattern favored Yitzhak Shamir, the Likud leader. Page A1
Likud Party supporters celebrated the party's slight advantage in election returns. Inside the party's campaign headquarters, candidates cheered television broadcasts. A14
Imports of South African uranium by Japan's giant utilities will end, they announced. The Tokyo Government has been worried by the growth of Japanese-South African trade. A1

Changes in the Soviet Government that are planned would give Mikhail Gorbachev a dangerous monopoly of power, Andrei Sakharov warned, reflecting what appears to be the view of many Soviet intellectuals. A1

Washington accused the Soviet Union of deploying advanced missiles in Afghanistan and said the missiles pose a threat to Pakistan. A Soviet press agency said Afghan forces had obtained ''long-range missiles'' but did not report their origin. A8
Major revision of a nuclear war plan is being completed by the Strategic Air Command because of new American and Soviet weapons systems and the elimination of a category of missiles in Europe. A7

Poland's Government is accused by Solidarity of seeking to provoke labor violence by closing the Lenin shipyard in Gdansk. The outlawed union said it would refrain from striking. A6 China's population continues to grow despite a policy limiting each couple to one child, which the Government said it is not strictly applying. Urbanization, however, may become an effective rein, a U.N. official said. A3
South Africa barred publication of the nation's most prominent opposition newspaper, The Weekly Mail, whose readership includes some affluent white South Africans. A3
C.I.A. cites doubts on Soviet economy A9
Israeli planes again attack Palestinians in Lebanon A14

NATIONAL A16-24 An economic gauge fell in September for the third time in the latest five months, the Commerce Department said. Economists cited the decline and other figures, as evidence that the economy has begun to slow. A1

A Medicare expansion is not popular with the elderly because of its high cost, even though it was supported eby interest groups for the elderly. A1 An agreement to freeze emissions of nitrogen oxides, a major source of acid rain and other serious air pollution problems, was signed by the United States, which joins 24 other industrialized nations. A24
A marine once held captive in Iran, who has suffered emotional troubles since being released, will be given an honorable discharge despite his desire to remain in the Marine Corps, officials say. A18
Aliens' rail trips grow more perilous A16
Court orders tighter rules on adopting wild horses A16
Hemophiliac awarded $1.6 million in AIDS case A17

POLITICS A20-22 Michael Dukakis's health is fine, his doctor said. He has suffered only a few minor ailments through life and has withstood a number of emotional stresses without professional counseling, he and his doctor said. A1
The Presidential candidates offer different approaches to America's role in the world. But with foreign affairstaking a back seat in the campaign, voters have only an outline of that difference. A1
George Bush would seek a summit with Mikhail Gorbachev ''at the earliest time that would serve the interests of world peace'' if elected President, Mr. Bush said. A20
Michael Dukakis took aim at Wall Street speculators and corrupt officials in speeches in the Middle West. ''Hard workers, not high rollers, built this country,'' he said. A20

''There have to be better candidates'' appears to be the main refrain from voters in Prineville, Ore., who are looking at the Presidential contenders a week before Election Day. A20 WASHINGTON TALK A24 REGIONAL B1-5 Lisa Steinberg was bruised so much when she arrived at St. Vincent's Medical Center that child abuse was immediately suspected, a doctor said at the trial of Joel Steinberg. B1
A new subway car wash is dangerous to employees and unable to clean any better than the old manual method, even though almost $26 million has been spent on it, a report said. B1
Joseph Lieberman has made fun of his opponent in the Senate campaign in Connecticut, Lowell Weicker, with an unlikely but potent political weapon: a snoozing bear cartoon. B1
Plans for a Chelsea health clinic to give needles to drug addicts in New York City will proceed, the Health Department said, despite protests that the clinic would be next to an elementary school. B1

The new witness in the Myerson trial is a housekeeper, who recalled Bess Myerson's and Carl Capasso's weekends at his estate. Her testimony followed Sukhreet Gabel's nine days on the witness stand. B3

A license to operate Shoreham at 25 percent of capacity was supported by the staff of the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission, an advance in Lilco's effort to win a license for the nuclear power plant. B2
New York City removes belongings of homeless from park B2
Forensic expert contradicts Davis prosecution testimony B2
